definition: To overcome initial social awkwardness; to relieve tension and get conversation going.

examples.sentence: He told a joke to break the ice at the meeting.
A fun activity can help break the ice on the first day of class.

wrongExamples: Be careful not to break the ice when you walk across the frozen lake.
He used a hammer to break the ice in the cooler.
She had to break the ice to get water from the well in winter.

idiom: hit the nail on the head
definition: To describe a situation or problem very accurately.

examples.sentence: When she said the project failed because of poor planning, she hit the nail on the head.

wrongExamples: He carefully hit the nail on the head while building the fence.
Make sure to hit the nail on the head to avoid bending it.
The carpenter hit the nail on the head with his hammer.

definition: Very rarely; something that does not happen often.

examples.sentence: We only get together once in a blue moon these days.

wrongExamples: The astronomer said we can see a blue moon once in a blue moon.
Once in a blue moon, the moon actually appears blue in the sky.
The lunar eclipse happens once in a blue moon according to the calendar.

definition: To reveal a secret or disclose something confidential.

examples.sentence: Don't spill the beans about the surprise party!

wrongExamples: Be careful not to spill the beans when you pour them into the pot.
I accidentally spilled the beans all over the kitchen floor.
She spilled the beans while cooking dinner and had to clean up the mess.

definition: Feeling ill or slightly sick.

examples.sentence: I stayed home today because I was feeling under the weather.

wrongExamples: The picnic table was placed under the weather vane for shade.
We stored the equipment under the weather-resistant tarp.
The plants grew better under the weather conditions this year.

definition: To face a difficult or unpleasant situation with courage.

examples.sentence: I hate going to the dentist, but I just need to bite the bullet and make an appointment.

wrongExamples: The soldier had to bite the bullet because there was no anesthesia available.
In the old western movies, they would bite the bullet during surgery.
He bit the bullet to test if it was real metal.

idiom: cost an arm and a leg
definition: To be extremely expensive.

examples.sentence: That new car costs an arm and a leg!
examples.usedIdiom: costs an arm and a leg

examples.sentence: Designer handbags cost an arm and a leg these days.

wrongExamples: The medical procedure cost him an arm and a leg that had to be amputated.
The accident cost an arm and a leg in terms of his injuries.
Insurance will cover the treatment that cost an arm and a leg to repair.

idiom: let the cat out of the bag
definition: To accidentally reveal a secret.

examples.sentence: She let the cat out of the bag about the engagement before the official announcement.

wrongExamples: When we arrived home, we let the cat out of the bag so it could roam freely.
The veterinarian let the cat out of the bag after the checkup.
Please let the cat out of the bag carefully so it doesn't escape outside.

definition: Something very easy to do.

examples.sentence: The exam was a piece of cake; I finished in 20 minutes.
Don't worry, assembling this furniture is a piece of cake.

wrongExamples: I brought a piece of cake to share at the party.
Would you like a piece of cake with your coffee?
She saved a piece of cake for her sister who came home late.

definition: Something that will never happen.

examples.sentence: He'll clean his room when pigs fly.
Sure, I'll lend you money again—when pigs fly!

wrongExamples: According to this fantasy book, magical things happen when pigs fly.
The children's story describes a world when pigs fly through the clouds.
When pigs fly overhead, the farmers know it's feeding time at the farm.

idiom: the ball is in your court
definition: It is now your turn to take action or make a decision.

examples.sentence: I've done all I can—the ball is in your court now.

wrongExamples: During the tennis match, the ball is in your court so you need to return it.
The ball is in your court, so pick it up and serve.
Make sure the ball is in your court before the other team scores.

definition: To work late into the night.

examples.sentence: She's been burning the midnight oil to finish her thesis.

wrongExamples: In the old days, people would literally burn the midnight oil in their lamps.
The historical reenactment showed how they used to burn the midnight oil for light.
Before electricity, families would burn the midnight oil to see at night.

definition: To get to the point without wasting time.

examples.sentence: Let's cut to the chase—what do you really want?
I don't have much time, so please cut to the chase.

wrongExamples: The film editor decided to cut to the chase scene to make it more exciting.
During editing, they cut to the chase sequence in the action movie.
The director wanted to cut to the chase scene earlier in the film.

definition: To go to bed or go to sleep.

examples.sentence: I'm exhausted. I think I'll hit the sack early tonight.

wrongExamples: The boxer practiced how to hit the sack during training.
In the gym, you need to hit the sack with proper form.
He hit the sack repeatedly to improve his punching technique.

definition: To pursue a mistaken or misguided course of action.

examples.sentence: If you think I took your keys, you're barking up the wrong tree.

wrongExamples: The dog was literally barking up the wrong tree—the squirrel was in the oak, not the pine.
My puppy keeps barking up the wrong tree when chasing animals.
The hunting dog was barking up the wrong tree during the expedition.

definition: To avoid talking about what is important; to delay or be indirect.

examples.sentence: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what happened.

wrongExamples: The hunters would beat around the bush to flush out the birds.
We had to beat around the bush to find where the ball landed.
Gardeners often beat around the bush to scare away pests.

definition: Something that seems bad at first but turns out to be good.

examples.sentence: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise—I found a much better one.

wrongExamples: The gift was a blessing in disguise because it was wrapped in plain paper.
She received a blessing in disguise at the costume party from the priest.
The mysterious package turned out to be a blessing in disguise—literally a disguised present.

definition: To become out of control.
wrongDefinitions: To hold something firmly in your hand.

examples.sentence: The party got out of hand when more people showed up than expected.

wrongExamples: The bird managed to get out of hand and flew away.
Try not to let the slippery fish get out of hand when cleaning it.
The ball got out of hand and rolled down the street.

definition: In a risky or precarious situation.

examples.sentence: You're on thin ice with your boss after missing that deadline.

wrongExamples: The ice skaters performed carefully because they were on thin ice.
Don't walk on thin ice—it might crack under your weight.
The frozen pond had people on thin ice that could break at any moment.

definition: To give up or admit defeat.

examples.sentence: After three failed attempts, he decided to throw in the towel.

wrongExamples: After the shower, please throw in the towel with the laundry.
He threw in the towel to help clean up the spill on the floor.
She threw in the towel as an extra gift with the bathroom set.

definition: Something very common and not very valuable.

examples.sentence: Smartphone apps are a dime a dozen these days.

wrongExamples: The candy store sells gumballs at a dime a dozen.
You can buy these pencils at a dime a dozen at the school supply sale.
The farmer's market offered eggs at a dime a dozen today.

definition: Said when someone you were just talking about arrives.

examples.sentence: We were just discussing John, and speak of the devil, here he comes!

wrongExamples: In the horror movie, they would speak of the devil to summon evil spirits.
The ritual required them to speak of the devil at midnight.
Never speak of the devil in a haunted house, according to superstition.

definition: The final problem in a series that makes a situation unbearable.

examples.sentence: Coming home to find the house a mess was the last straw.

wrongExamples: I used the last straw from the package for my drink.
The last straw in the box was bent, so I threw it away.
She grabbed the last straw from the dispenser at the restaurant.

definition: To make a bad situation worse.
wrongDefinitions: To make a good situation better.

examples.sentence: To add insult to injury, it started raining after my car broke down.

wrongExamples: The bully would add insult to injury by calling names after pushing someone.
In the argument, he decided to add insult to injury by bringing up old fights.
She would add insult to injury during fights, which wasn't helpful.

definition: What you do is more important than what you say.

examples.sentence: He promises to help, but actions speak louder than words.

wrongExamples: In the noisy room, actions speak louder than words because you can't hear anything.
During the silent film, actions speak louder than words since there's no dialogue.
With the broken microphone, actions speak louder than words at the presentation.

definition: A situation where you can enjoy two different opportunities at once.

examples.sentence: Working from home gives me the best of both worlds—flexibility and career growth.

wrongExamples: The travelers enjoyed the best of both worlds by visiting Europe and Asia.
The restaurant offers the best of both worlds with locations in two countries.
She got the best of both worlds by inheriting property in two different continents.

definition: It's better to do something late than not do it at all.

examples.sentence: You finally finished the project! Well, better late than never.

wrongExamples: The late train is better late than never arriving at all.
I always say better late than never when my delayed flight finally lands.
The package was better late than never after being lost in shipping.

idiom: by the skin of your teeth
definition: To barely succeed or escape something.

examples.sentence: I passed the exam by the skin of my teeth.
examples.usedIdiom: by the skin of my teeth

wrongExamples: The dentist explained that plaque forms by the skin of your teeth.
Cavities develop by the skin of your teeth if you don't brush properly.
Tooth enamel protects by the skin of your teeth from damage.

definition: Don't waste time worrying about things that have already happened.

examples.sentence: Yes, you made a mistake, but don't cry over spilled milk.

wrongExamples: The toddler started to cry, but I said don't cry over spilled milk—we can clean it up.
When the glass tipped over, I told the kids don't cry over spilled milk, just grab a towel.
She began to cry over spilled milk on the kitchen floor, but it was easily cleaned.

idiom: every cloud has a silver lining
definition: There is something good in every bad situation.

examples.sentence: I know you're disappointed, but every cloud has a silver lining.

wrongExamples: The meteorologist explained that every cloud has a silver lining due to light reflection.
In the sunset, every cloud has a silver lining from the sun's rays.
During the storm, every cloud has a silver lining visible through the darkness.
